content.section_header: Select the SYNONYM for each bold word

content.question: Fear of heights prevented Ryan from reaching the apex of the Eiffel Tower.
During India’s struggle for independence, Gandhi went on several hunger strikes and was ready to be martyred for the cause.
A multitude assembled to catch a glimpse of the candidate on her stop in town.
Placed in a glass of water, the scion from the philodendron should grow roots in a few weeks.
Suzanne was happy for the chance to vindicate her claim that she had discovered Mark Twain’s diaries.

content.section_header: Select the ANTONYM for each bold word

content.question: The 21st Amendment rescinded the 18th Amendment, thereby ending Prohibition.
The family revered their matriarch, and they came from the four corners of the globe to celebrate her 90th birthday with her.
The stranger was so suave that everybody was immediately put at ease.
The artist’s sketch was a travesty of what really happened at the rally.
The sordid facts of the bribery scandal ruined the careers of all the people involved.

content.section_header: Choose the best way to complete each sentence or answer each question

content.question: Collusion between businesses to artificially drive up demand for a product may be all of the following except
Indictments involve what kind of charges?
Which of the following does not have to do with incinerating?
The brothers’ exchanges could be so vitriolic that strangers might think they hated each other. What element characterizes the exchanges?
Which of the following is not judicial?

content.section_header: Read the passage and answer the question

passage: Judicial interpreters are people fluent in at least two languages who help those who are indicted with a crime, and who don’t speak English well, understand what is happening throughout the judicial process. These interpreters are highly fluent in what is sometimes called “legalese”—the specialized language of the court.

Working with attorneys, judicial interpreters help individuals understand what is happening when they must stand before the judge to plead guilty or not guilty to a crime. They must convey not just the meaning of the words spoken, but the tone as well—for example, when the tone from a sarcastic judge is vitriolic.

Judicial interpreters are always learning. Sometimes they are sent materials to study so they can become familiar with specific technical words and phrases related to the evidence in a trial. An interpreter working on a case in which someone is indicted for setting a fire might have to learn the names of chemicals used for incineration. Or, if a case involves a religious group, the interpreter may need to learn about beliefs, practices, and important religious figures such as martyrs.

content.question: In line 1, judicial means
The meaning of indicted (line 2) is
In line 12, vitriolic most nearly means
The word incineration (line 18) most nearly means
In line 21, martyrs means
options: those who have died for their beliefs
